posts.content: What do you think is Meno's basic difficulty at the opening of this dialogue? Why is he not able to define virtue? How does this difficulty illustrate the difference between a definition and instances of that definition (70a-80d)? As Socrates turns to look for his own definition of virtue, what objection does he face (80d-e)? How does he attempt to answer that objection? (Hint: what does he mean by recollection?) (81b-82a) How does Socrates try to illustrate his theory of recollection through his interaction with the slave boy (82b and following)? To help you understand this complicated exchange note that Plato is trying to get the slave boy to recognize the following geometrical truth: A square (BEHD) whose area is twice that of a given square (ABCD) is the square (BEHD) formed using the diagonal of the square (ABCD) as one of its four sides. {/* */} During the exchange, does Socrates ever teach the boy or give the boy new information? Or does the boy discover everything for himself? Can you think of other examples of this kind of learning? Can you think of an example where you must have already known "something", but if someone had asked you before, you would have probably said you didn't know it? What is the difference between knowledge and opinion that begins to be discussed at 97b? How does Socrates illustrate this difference with his obscure reference to the statues of Daedalus and runaway slaves? How does one "tie" down an opinion so that it becomes knowledge (98a)? If holding a "true opinion/belief" means that we believe what is true (that is, we have an accurate belief about the world), why do we need something called "knowledge"? In Plato's terms, why is better to have a true opinion that has been "tied down"? Can you think of some concrete situations where "true opinion" might not be sufficient, perhaps a situation where having "true opinion" but not knowledge is dangerous or simply unsatisfying?

## A Question for Thales

Thales wanted to find a single cause or explanation for the universe. 
In pursuit of such an explanation he proposed that the entire universe 
is fundamentally made up of one element: water

But if everything is water, how is Thales to account for our "lived experience" of variety and difference. Maybe everything is water. But why doesn't it all look like water?
 
If you think about it, this is still a question today that needs explaining. 

I can point to an ice cube and you can tell me it is water. 
But then I can point to a glass of water and you will tell me it is also water. 
Again, I can point to a cloud in the sky and again you will tell me it is also water. 

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question>How can three different things, with such diverse properties, appearances, and behaviors really be the "same" thing?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<span id="anaximenes-demo"/>

## Anaximenes on Condensation and Rarefaction 

Anaximenes took the above question seriously. 

If we're going to be able to explain the world in terms of a single cause (where this cause is some singular "stuff"), then the burden is on us to explain how this stuff can appear so "qualitatively different".

In the scene below, there are three qualitatively different objects (perhaps one is "hard" and one is "somewhat firm" and the third is "very soft"). Let us imagine that each is composed of "air" (imagined as cubes), which Anaximenes proposed as an alternative to water. 

Explore the three objects below. (Zoom in and out, rotate around and inspect each object.) The consider the questions below.

# Reading Questions Work through these reading questions first, but consider the class notes that follow. ## Parmenides Please make sure to read the editorial introduction to the fragments from Parmenides. According to this introduction, what are the three parts of Parmenides poem? What is the central message of the section of his poem titled "Truth" (see fragments 2-8)? What conclusion does Parmenides reach about the possibility of change (see esp. 8.12-22)? What kinds of reasons does he offer for this claim? How might it connect to the two different "routes" introduced in fragment 6 or the division between "that which is" and "that which is not"? What is the central message of the third section titled Doxa, which begins at 8.50? Why are the opinions of mortals "deceitful"? Consider especially the "opinion" (or doxa) in fragment 19. How does this "opinion" compare to the truth asserted in the earlier section? ## Parmenides vs. Anaximenes Another way to think about Parmenides' contribution is to come back to Anaximenes's original position. Parmenides looked at Anaximenes's account of the world and asked some troubling questions. Anaximenes's used the different degrees of "density" (i.e. the space between air particles) to explain qualitative difference. [But recall our earlier 3D model illustrating Anaximenes's position](class-14#anaximenes-demo). Then ask, what is the "stuff" between the "cubes"? In other words, what is the space between the air particles? In this example, explore the "sphere" below. Try especially to go "inside" the sphere? (a "mouse scroll" should allow you to move inside and back out of the sphere). What do you see there? After exploring the "sphere", consider the following questions: What is the sphere? And consequently, what is the stuff between the cubes in which those cubes are suspended or floating? Is it NOTHING? If so, since each object has the same amount of cubes and "nothing" between them, shouldn't they all be qualitatively the same? Is it SOMETHING? If it is something, what, according Anaximenes must it be? And if the space between the cubes is just more of this "something", why would this threaten Anaximenes's explanation qualitative difference? ## Zeno According to the editorial introduction to the section on Zeno, what is Zeno's relation to Parmenides? How is Zeno trying to show the consequences of Parmenides's position? Consider how this is argued for in fragment 1 (p. 66-67). Consider fragment 5 (p. 68) closely. How does this fragment attempt to prove that if there are many things, then, paradoxically, these many things must be both finite and infinite at the same time? Consider fragment 6 and 7. How do these arguments attempt to prove that our ideas of motion are impossible and contradictory? Consider fragment 12. How does Zeno argue for the absurdity of thinking about "place" as something that exists? What is your reaction to Zeno’s argument against motion in fragments 6 and 7? Do the arguments seem convincing? In what way? Since Zeno, like us, clearly has the experience of motion in his daily life, what do you think the ultimate goal of his arguments is? What might he be trying say about our sense-experience of the world? # Class Notes on Parmenides ## From Nothingness to a World without Change Parmenides's central positions comes from taking the idea of "nothingness" very seriously. As an example, stop for a moment and try to think of "nothing". Can you do it? What do you think of when try to think of "nothing"? Describe what you "see" when you do this Parmenides claims it can't be done. If you're thing of "anything", then you are still thinking of "something". Thus, if you claim to be successfully thinking of "nothing", then you are actually still thinking of "something". For Parmenides, "nothing" is completely unintelligible. This might seem like a small claim, but Parmenides draws out some big implications from the unintelligibility of nothingness. The most important implication is what it means for one of our most common experiences, namely our experience of change. In direct opposition to Heraclitus, Parmenides asserts that change is actually not happening and cannot happen. Despite what your senses tell you, nothing changes. Why is Parmenides so confident? He gives us a version of the following argument. 1) First, if something comes to be from "already being", then it already is, and therefore it did not actually come to be. Consider P. 60, fragment 8, line 18-20) 2) Second, if something comes to be from "non-being", then it comes from nothing. (But nothing, if it is really nothing, can't become something because it would first have to be something. Parmenides' view is often captured in the phrase "nothing comes from nothing".) Consider what he says on p. 59, fragment 8, line 6: > "For what birth will you seek out for it? How and from what did it grow? For what is not I will allow you neither to say nor to think…" We could formalize this argument even more: 1) If E (Exists), then A (Already exists) (p. 60, fragment 8, line 18-20) 2) If ~E (Not Exists), then N (nothing, because nothing comes from nothing) (p. 59, frag. 8, line 5-17) 3) Things either E (exists) or ~E (do not exists) C) Therefore, Everything A (Already exists) or N (is Nothing). Does this argument remind you of anything we've seen before? Why do you think the arguments are so similar? The result is that there is only one thing in the universe, it is the "What is" and it never changes in any way. ## Other Descriptions of the "What is" Let's consider more closely what this "What is" or "Being" is that Parmenides says never goes in or out of existence. Here you might consider closely Fragment 8, line 23 and following. I'll focus on four key characteristics below. ### 1. It is necessarily one, unified, and indivisible Why can't the "What is" be divided? Fredrick Copelston explains as follows: > "Because if it is not one but divided, then it must be divided by something other than itself. But Being cannot be divided by something other than itself, for besides being there is nothing." Consider the following example. Imagine I have a line.

And then I want to cut this line into distinct parts, so I break it up, like so: -|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|- If the horizontal line represents the "what is", and the "what is" is the only thing in the world that exists, what are the vertical lines in the above illustration? According to Paremenides, they can only be more of the "what is". Thus, the division is only an illusion. It is actually impossible to break up the line or divide it because whatever you try to use to separate or divide the line will just be more of the line itself. ### 2. It is complete - nothing can be added to it. Why might it seem like a problem if something could be "added" to the "What is"? Consider Fragment 8.24: > "And not all more in any way, which would keep it from holding together or at all less, but it is full of what-is…" Again Copelston states "…anything that was added to 'being', would itself be MORE being" (and thus would already be a part of being). ### 3. It is immovable, unchanging, and continuous Consider Fragment 8:25: > "But unchanging in the limits of great bonds it is without starting or ceasing…" Why can't the "What is" move? You might consider, to where it would it move. If it tries to move to another place, what will already be there before it gets there? Won't the "What is" simply find that it was always already there. ### 4. It is necessary and eternal. The "What is" can never have first moment in which it begins to be. Nor can it every cease to be. Consider Fragment 8.30: > "Remaining the same and in the same and by itself it lies and so remains there fixed; for mighty necessity holds it in bonds of a limit which holds it on all sides." This inference seems pretty straightforward. If the material stuff of the world cannot go in or out of being, if there is anything at all, it must have always exist. It therefore must be eternal and necessary. ## Conclusion: Appearance Versus Reality. If Parmenides is correct and the world really is an indivisible, unmoving and unchanging, single thing, what does this say about our experience of the world? If reason proves that changes is impossible, and yet our senses still perceive change, what are we supposed to conclude about experience of change? Parmenides thinks we must conclude that "all change is an illusion" and further "our experience of change is a deception". This corollary is perhaps Parmenides' greatest and most troubling contribution to the history of philosophy. By pointing out that reason tells us change cannot happen, despite the fact that our senses tell us that change does happen, he has created a dramatic division between "Reason" and "Sense", "Reality" and "Appearance". For him, reason proves (prior to any experience and sensation) that our senses deceive us and don't provide us with reliable access to the "real". He insists that reality is really very different than it appears. Thus, if I want to get access to the "real", I need to shut out my senses, and uses my reason alone to access what is truly true. And I want to call your attention to this now because this will become Plato's central inheritance from Parmenides.

As always, please be sure to read the biographical introduction to each of our thinkers.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Chapter 4 is the heart of his discussion of pleasure.</Question>
<Question level={2}>How is pleasure different from movement (this is complicated, but give it your best shot)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What is his ultimate definition of pleasure?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How does pleasure relate to activity?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>


<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>If pleasure is related to activity in the way stated in chapter 4, how does Aristotle use this fact to explain how some pleasures can be good and some can be bad (see esp. 1175b25)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What does this say about the value of pleasure in itself? Can pleasure be either good or bad in and of itself? Why or why not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>


<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>Can you think of a time that pleasure/pain was a good guide to "right action" or a good decision? Can you think of a time that pleasure/pain led you to a "wrong action" or a bad decision?</Question>
<Question level={2}>If so, what was different about these two cases? </Question>
<Question level={2}>What other conditions determine when pleasure/pain is a good guide and when it is bad guide?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

For: Aristotle, Ethics, Book X, cc. 6-8


<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Book X.6-8 closes the Ethics in the way Book I opened, with a discussion of the good life.</Question>
<Question level={2}>Is book X's conclusions about the good life consistent with Book I (and the things we've learned along the way)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Just for the sake of review, note that in chapter 6, he states "happiness is not a state/disposition".</Question>
<Question level={2}>Can you understand why he makes this distinction? Is this consistent with what we've read so far? (Another way of asking the question would be: why are happiness and virtue not identical? What is different about them?)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What's the difference between a virtuous activity and a "pleasant amusement" (c. 6)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What does Aristotle recognize as the "highest activity" (c. 7)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Are there any reasons given to support this conclusion? (There are at least six.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How does this life differ from the life lived according to "practical virtues" (c. 7, near 1177a22)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Why does he say that the contemplative life is "too high for man"?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Is it odd that he would still urge us to pursue this life?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>A few more differences between the "two lives" are discussed in c. 8.</Question>
<Question level={2}>How do these two lives differ in terms of needing external goods?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>In chapter 7, why does Aristotle state that the life of contemplation is the most self-sufficient life (see in particular pp. 440-441)? </Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does he say it is more self-sufficient than the life of the politician or the warrior?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Can you think of an example to illustrate the difference he is trying to describe?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

data.title: Class 32 Guided Reading Questions
data.description: Aristotle, Ethics, Book X, cc. 4-5 and Aristotle, Ethics, Book X, cc. 6-8

posts.content:
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Where does Polus thinks Gorgias has gone wrong? What is he prepared to admit that Gorgias was not (p. 27)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Be familiar with the four kinds of flattery.</Question>
<Question level={2}>What are the four corresponding types of expertise?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How is flattery distinguished from expertise (see pp. 30-33)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>On p. 35, Socrates asserts a position that is shocking to Polus. He then attempts to prove it by asserting a paradox.</Question>
<Question level={2}>What is this paradox (see bottom of p. 35)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How does Socrates prove this paradox using the distinction between “doing what he thinks is best” and “doing what he wants”?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>Despite the objections of Polus, why does Socrates think the unjust dictator is the least powerful person? What else does Socrates think is required for true power and why? (See esp. pp. 34-35.)</Question>
<Question level={2}>Compare this to one example of injustice or attempt at domination that we see today.</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why might Socrates see such an act of injustice as an example “impotence” rather than “real power”?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>At p. 46, Socrates adds an even more shocking and unbelievable assertion.</Question>
<Question level={2}>What is this assertion (p. 46)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Provide a general description of Polus’s response (pp. 46-48)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>At the bottom of p. 48, the discussion turns to Socrates’ argument for this new paradox.</Question>
<Question level={2}>According to Socrates, what makes something admirable? What makes something contemptible? (Three different options are mentioned.)</Question>
<Question level={2}>For which of these three options is it decided that doing wrong (or injustice) is contemptible and therefore also worse than suffering wrong?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Now, finish the argument . . .why is going un-punished worse than being punished?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>Why does Socrates think it is better to be punished for injustice than to go unpunished?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Can you think of any contemporary examples where this might actually be true?</Question>
<Question level={2}>In other words, are there any contemporary examples where punishment for injustice actually makes people happier?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Are there examples of people who go unpunished and thus become increasingly unhappy?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Where does Callicles think Polus has gone wrong?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>With Polus especially, Socrates tried to point out the excessive reliance on appearance and neglect of the unchanging truth. Here, how does Callicles invert this charge and accuse Socrates of paying attention to appearances only (p. 65)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What kind of distinction does Callicles appeal to in order to make his point?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to Callicles, who are the people that make the laws? What kind of people are they?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What kind of laws do they make? Why?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Callicles' complaint against philosophy (p. 67)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does he say philosophers are “completely out of touch with human nature”?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What does Callicles think is the appropriate reason to pursue philosophy?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Why does Socrates praise Callicles' speech?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How is he said to differ from Gorgias and Polus (p. 70-71)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What are the complications Socrates raises for Callicles' position?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What distinctions get drawn between 'superior', 'stronger', 'better', 'cleverest'?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Socrates' point by bringing up the examples of the doctor, coat maker, cobbler? (p. 76-77)</Question>
<Question level={2}>How might it problematize the belief that the 'cleverest' should have the most?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Finally, what is Callicles' final definition of what it means to be 'superior'?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Does it share any similarities with Polus' earliest description of the rhetorician? How so?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>How does Callicles's evaluation of philosophy parallel some of the ways we saw—at the beginning of the semester—people valuing the utility of a “liberal arts education” without necessarily valuing the "liberal arts" (see pp. 67-68)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How does Socrates turn the discussion in a new direction at the opening of this section?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Why does Callicles believe self-discipline to be “folly”?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Accordingly, to Callicles, why do we typically praise self-control/temperance and justice?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Does he take a different view towards courage?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>In short, what is the happy life according to Callicles (bttm. of p. 79)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>And why aren’t most people capable of living it? What do they lack?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>In response, Socrates invokes a couple of examples involving leaky jars. What is his point here? What do these examples illustrate?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>On page 81, what is the alternative vision of the happy life that Socrates wants to present to Callicles?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Socrates proposes another example of Callicles’ description of the happy life: the life of perpetual scratching and itching (pp. 82-83). Why is Callicles forced to admit that this is the happy life?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How does Socrates respond? In his view, what absurd consequences seem to follow?</Question>
<Question level={2}>To what familiar distinction does Socrates leads us in light of these consequences? (Familiar in the sense that Aristotle made a similar kind of distinction.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Why won’t Callicles admit that pleasure and the good are not identical?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why is this a problem for Socrates?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Following Callicles’ refusal are two separate arguments that try to establish that the good and the pleasant are different. Can you discern the “essential” premises of these two arguments?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>The leaky jars example is introduced to illustrate the two rival kinds of lives being proposed by Callicles and Socrates.</Question>
<Question level={2}>Which life seems like the best life to you?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does it seem like the best life?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What concerns do you have about the alternative?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
